The grid layout

We can use grid systems to create page layouts using combinations of rows and columns that live within a container.

Usage

  1. Start by creating a .container element. The .grid-row elements will be placed within here to allow for correct alignment and padding.
  2. Use .grid-rows to make horizontal groups of .cells.
  3. Only a .cell may be an immediate child of a .grid-row. Any other element is likely to become misaligned.
  4. You must place your content within a .cell.
  5. Our grid system is 12 columns wide. You can add an additional .cell--[COLUMNS]-col-[SIZE] class to a .cell to make it span [COLUMNS] number of columns, on the [SIZE] (and up) breakpoint.
    E.g., .cell--6-col-small will give you a 6 column wide cell, for screens that are small and up.

Other notes

  • The .container component sets the max-width of its block, and adds padding (a gutter) on the left and right of itself.
  • This additional padding ensures that the .grid-row doesn't run off the page/cause horizontal scroll bars because of its negative margins.
  • Each .cell has left/right padding to create space between the columns (same as the gutter above).
  • Each .grid-row has a negative left/right margin that is the same width as the gutter. The negative margins offset the first/last cells' gutters.
    • We do this to prevent the use of complicated variations on the :nth-child selectors (no, :first/last-child won't work); and
    • To ensure that the grid content aligns correctly with non-grid content
  • There is no top/bottom padding/margin on .grid-row or .cell components. The developer must decide how they want to vertically space their content.
  • Grids may be nested. A .grid-row can't be an immediate child of another .grid-row, so place it inside a .cell first.

Configuration options

Class name Effect Remarks
.page-wrapper Give the page some top padding to compensate for the fixed header.
Placed on the body tag.		 Required.
.content-wrapper Placed on the main tag.
This ensures that the footer always appears at the bottom of the page. 		Required.
.container Defines an element to be a container component Required on the outermost div
.grid-row Defines an element to be a grid component Required. Placed within a container.
.cell Defines an element to be a cell component Required.
Must be the immediate child of a grid-row.
Defaults to an auto-width cell (but 100% width on mobile)
.cell--N-col Sets the cell to be N cols wide on mobile screens Optional on a cell element (N is 1-12 inclusive)
.cell--N-col-large Sets the cell to be N cols wide on > large screens Optional on a cell element (N is 1-12 inclusive)
.cell--N-col-medium Sets the cell to be N cols wide on > medium screens Optional on a cell element (N is 1-12 inclusive)
.cell--N-col-small Sets the cell to be N cols wide on > small screens Optional on a cell element (N is 1-12 inclusive)
.grid-row--align-[POSITION][-SCREEN_SIZE] Vertical/horizontally align the .cells inside a .grid-row for certain screen sizes Optional. Placed on .grid-row
POSITION: Can be left, center, right; or top, middle, bottom
SCREEN_SIZE: Can be small, medium, large, or excluded (will set for all screen sizes)
.cell--align-[POSITION][-SCREEN_SIZE] Vertically aligns the individual .cell for certain screen sizes Optional. Placed on .cell
POSITION: Can be top, middle, or bottom
SCREEN_SIZE: Can be small, medium, large, or excluded (will set for all screen sizes)

Breakpoint breakdown

Breakpoint name Size Scss variable Media query
Large Screens larger than 1200px $screen-large @include breakpoint($screen-large) {}
Medium Screens larger than 992px $screen-medium @include breakpoint($screen-medium) {}
Small Screens larger than 768px $screen-small @include breakpoint($screen-small) {}
Mobile No breakpoint required n/a We are mobile first, so the default styles are mobile
